If the Church adapted to more modern thinking, it might not face a loss of followers. I've heard that many people are unsatisfied with the Church's stance on these issues. They feel that the Church's views are incorrect. For example, if someone supports abortion and wants to stay within the Church, it might make them uncomfortable if the Church teaches it's completely wrong. The same goes for same-sex marriage. People might not want to follow a religion that disagrees with their personal beliefs. I don't see any reason why priests can't be married or why women can't become priests. However, I'm not sure if these changes would have prevented the current situation. It's hard to say if priests would have acted differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests. The Church argues that priests are devoted to God, but I don't see why they can't also have a family life. It's perplexing that priests can't balance their job and their personal life like everyone else.

When you post something online, it enters a public forum. It's completely public. You can't control what others think or do. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. When you put something out there, it shapes people's opinions about you. If you're talking about destruction or shootings, someone might react. You can't put that out there for the world to see. The internet is accessible to everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you might receive a bulletin. It wasn't the school that received the bulletin; someone went to the school and reported it. They have to act on it, because if they don't and something happens, they could have prevented it. However, you don't know what to take seriously, because some people just joke around. Like in our school, it could have been a sociology project gone wrong. I mean, what happened was someone overheard something in the school and reported it. When we found out who the person was, a friend of his checked his Facebook and got worried because there were some concerning messages. In light of the situation, it became serious. When you put something online, there's no invasion of privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. You can't control what others think or find. I don't think school officials should be friends with students on Myspace and Facebook. But if something is brought to their attention, there's no invasion of privacy. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I mean, I don't think they should monitor phone conversations and texts. But if something is brought to their attention, it's a different story. Like a teacher shouldn't create a Facebook or Myspace account under a different name and befriend students. That's the same as not wanting to know your residents if they go out and drink and post pictures on Facebook. It's not my place to know that, so I don't want that connection.

My understanding is that they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This moved it down from a criminal offense to more of a traffic ticket. It's something you get cited for, instead of being arrested and brought in. If someone gets caught and cited, for job interviews and other things like that, the consequences which are usually the worst part of having a drug charge, don't necessarily go away when it's decriminalized. However, the argument is that it costs a lot to arrest people, bring them in, book them, house them, and go through the court process. This includes paying for public defenders, judges, and the state attorney's office. So, when looking at financially troubled municipalities, many aren't willing to make this kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. However, in a place like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, it makes sense. The municipality now has more money to spend on public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's important because you don't want marijuana to be everywhere, all over the streets. There are other reasons why it shouldn't necessarily be legalized. For example, if it were completely legalized, it could be sold in gas stations, and people would be smoking it everywhere. That could lead to a lot of people smoking and driving, which is still taboo in many places. I also feel that it would be awkward for people. In terms of their effects, alcohol has more debilitating effects on motor skills, but marijuana has a more adverse effect on one's lifestyle. Both have their adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people exercise moderation, while others don't. It makes it hard to generalize about the substance because people react differently. However, I definitely think they both have their own adverse effects.

I was raised in a Christian household, so homosexuality is a bit of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, but I don’t necessarily agree with their lifestyle. However, I believe it should be legalized. I don’t think it should be a national issue, but rather something that each state decides on its own. The president shouldn’t decide for the entire country.

Many states are democratic, and many are republican. Democratic states will push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. You chose to live there, so you shouldn’t disagree with that decision if the state decides to legalize gay marriage.

I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don’t think the president should decide for the entire country. I don’t agree with his ban on it. He doesn’t live in every state, so he shouldn’t be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. I think some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he’ll be out of office in a couple of years. If a democratic president wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, it will just go back and forth. For instance, the Church is not very accepting of topics like same-sex marriage, abortion, and birth control. These strong views can be seen as old-fashioned. If the Church adapted to more modern thinking, it might not face a loss of followers. I've heard that many people are unsatisfied with the Church's stance on these issues. They feel that the Church's views are incorrect. For example, if someone supports abortion and wants to stay within the Church, it might make them uncomfortable if the Church teaches it's completely wrong. The same goes for same-sex marriage. People might not want to follow a religion that disagrees with their personal beliefs. I don't see any reason why priests can't be married or why women can't become priests. However, I'm not sure if these changes would have prevented the current situation. It's hard to say if priests would have acted differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests. The Church argues that priests are devoted to God, but I don't see why they can't also have a family life. It's perplexing that priests can't balance their job and their personal life like everyone else.

Ok.
The war in Iraq.
Well,
To start from the beginning, I don’t think the government was entirely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which in reality had little to do with each other. But the government made it seem otherwise and played on the emotions of the American people still outraged by the 9/11 attacks, and the invasion of Iraq began in 2003.
Um,
I,
I myself am generally against war, especially a preemptive strike. I think the war in Iraq is, in many ways, a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes.
A tremendous number of American soldiers have died, and that’s horrible. What they were doing is that they were removing the country’s government and I really don’t think the American government was prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that ensued. And here, the United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, a similar thing they tried to do in Vietnam by pushing out Communists and upholding democracy.
But it's not going to be a clear victory like it wasn’t in Vietnam because there are insurgents, and it’s hard to put them down when you’re not fighting an actual army, you’re fighting citizens.
So, I think first of all, we shouldn’t have gotten into war in the first place, cause I’m against it in pretty much all cases. But if you’re going to go to war with a country, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government wasn’t prepared enough for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government. We’re still there today, almost at the end of 2006, and we’re still trying to train the Iraqi troops and police to be able to police their own country. It’s a long process.
I think the U.S. government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. We shouldn’t be naïve about that because implementing a new form of government takes years, and it’s not an easy thing to do. It was a long struggle in our own country to get to the powerful government we are today, with lots of tension and even civil war.
So, the war in Iraq, it’s a difficult decision. It was kind of my feeling in the 2004 presidential election when I was thinking about who I would vote for. One of my reasons to vote for George Bush was to let him finish what he started. But once you go in, how can you abandon them? We took away their government and their way of life, so how can we abandon them now? It’s probably something we should try to see through to its finish, but there’s also the consideration of the astronomical number of American casualties.
I mean, if we’re invading Iraq to make it a democratic nation, why just Iraq? Why not all these other countries? I think the big reason is the oil issue, and this is where we’re getting our oil from. It’s usually about money and controlling resources.
And another thing to consider is that before going into war, it was said that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but no weapons were ever found. Places like North Korea, we know they have weapons of mass destruction, but we’re not making any attacks against them. So, I don’t think the U.S. government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions.
I just hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

When you post something online, it enters a public forum. It's completely public. You can't control what others think or do. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. When you put something out there, it shapes people's opinions about you. If you're talking about destruction or shootings, someone might react. You can't put that out there for the world to see. The internet is accessible to everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you might receive a bulletin. It wasn't the school that received the bulletin; someone went to the school and reported it. They have to act on it, because if they don't and something happens, they could have prevented it. However, you don't know what to take seriously, because some people just joke around. Like in our school, it could have been a sociology project gone wrong. I mean, what happened was someone overheard something in the school and reported it. When we found out who the person was, a friend of his checked his Facebook and got worried because there were some concerning messages. In light of the situation, it became serious. When you put something online, there's no invasion of privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. You can't control what others think or find. I don't think school officials should be friends with students on Myspace and Facebook. But if something is brought to their attention, there's no invasion of privacy. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I mean, I don't think they should monitor phone conversations and texts. But if something is brought to their attention, it's a different story. Like a teacher shouldn't create a Facebook or Myspace account under a different name and befriend students. That's the same as not wanting to know your residents if they go out and drink and post pictures on Facebook. It's not my place to know that, so I don't want that connection.

My understanding is that they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This moved it down from a criminal offense to more of a traffic ticket. It's something you get cited for, instead of being arrested and brought in. If someone gets caught and cited, for job interviews and other things like that, the consequences which are usually the worst part of having a drug charge, don't necessarily go away when it's decriminalized. However, the argument is that it costs a lot to arrest people, bring them in, book them, house them, and go through the court process. This includes paying for public defenders, judges, and the state attorney's office. So, when looking at financially troubled municipalities, many aren't willing to make this kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. However, in a place like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, it makes sense. The municipality now has more money to spend on public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's important because you don't want marijuana to be everywhere, all over the streets. There are other reasons why it shouldn't necessarily be legalized. For example, if it were completely legalized, it could be sold in gas stations, and people would be smoking it everywhere. That could lead to a lot of people smoking and driving, which is still taboo in many places. I also feel that it would be awkward for people. In terms of their effects, alcohol has more debilitating effects on motor skills, but marijuana has a more adverse effect on one's lifestyle. Both have their adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people exercise moderation, while others don't. It makes it hard to generalize about the substance because people react differently. However, I definitely think they both have their own adverse effects.

transformed_texts: I think that in several ways, the Catholic Church needs to change. Their views are somewhat outdated, and many people are turning away from it. For instance, the Church is not very accepting of topics like same-sex marriage, abortion, and birth control. These strong views can be seen as old-fashioned. If the Church adapted to more modern thinking, it might not face a loss of followers. I've heard that many people are unsatisfied with the Church's stance on these issues. They feel that the Church's views are incorrect. For example, if someone supports abortion and wants to stay within the Church, it might make them uncomfortable if the Church teaches it's completely wrong. The same goes for same-sex marriage. People might not want to follow a religion that disagrees with their personal beliefs. I don't see any reason why priests can't be married or why women can't become priests. However, I'm not sure if these changes would have prevented the current situation. It's hard to say if priests would have acted differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests. The Church argues that priests are devoted to God, but I don't see why they can't also have a family life. It's perplexing that priests can't balance their job and their personal life like everyone else.

Ok.
The war in Iraq.
Well,
To start from the beginning, I don’t think the government was entirely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which in reality had little to do with each other. But the government made it seem otherwise and played on the emotions of the American people still outraged by the 9/11 attacks, and the invasion of Iraq began in 2003.
Um,
I,
I myself am generally against war, especially a preemptive strike. I think the war in Iraq is, in many ways, a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes.
A tremendous number of American soldiers have died, and that’s horrible. What they were doing is that they were removing the country’s government and I really don’t think the American government was prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that ensued. And here, the United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, a similar thing they tried to do in Vietnam by pushing out Communists and upholding democracy.
But it's not going to be a clear victory like it wasn’t in Vietnam because there are insurgents, and it’s hard to put them down when you’re not fighting an actual army, you’re fighting citizens.
So, I think first of all, we shouldn’t have gotten into war in the first place, cause I’m against it in pretty much all cases. But if you’re going to go to war with a country, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government wasn’t prepared enough for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government. We’re still there today, almost at the end of 2006, and we’re still trying to train the Iraqi troops and police to be able to police their own country. It’s a long process.
I think the U.S. government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. We shouldn’t be naïve about that because implementing a new form of government takes years, and it’s not an easy thing to do. It was a long struggle in our own country to get to the powerful government we are today, with lots of tension and even civil war.
So, the war in Iraq, it’s a difficult decision. It was kind of my feeling in the 2004 presidential election when I was thinking about who I would vote for. One of my reasons to vote for George Bush was to let him finish what he started. But once you go in, how can you abandon them? We took away their government and their way of life, so how can we abandon them now? It’s probably something we should try to see through to its finish, but there’s also the consideration of the astronomical number of American casualties.
I mean, if we’re invading Iraq to make it a democratic nation, why just Iraq? Why not all these other countries? I think the big reason is the oil issue, and this is where we’re getting our oil from. It’s usually about money and controlling resources.
And another thing to consider is that before going into war, it was said that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but no weapons were ever found. Places like North Korea, we know they have weapons of mass destruction, but we’re not making any attacks against them. So, I don’t think the U.S. government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions.
I just hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

When you post something online, it enters a public forum. It's completely public. You can't control what others think or do. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. When you put something out there, it shapes people's opinions about you. If you're talking about destruction or shootings, someone might react. You can't put that out there for the world to see. The internet is accessible to everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you might receive a bulletin. It wasn't the school that received the bulletin; someone went to the school and reported it. They have to act on it, because if they don't and something happens, they could have prevented it. However, you don't know what to take seriously, because some people just joke around. Like in our school, it could have been a sociology project gone wrong. I mean, what happened was someone overheard something in the school and reported it. When we found out who the person was, a friend of his checked his Facebook and got worried because there were some concerning messages. In light of the situation, it became serious. When you put something online, there's no invasion of privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. You can't control what others think or find. I don't think school officials should be friends with students on Myspace and Facebook. But if something is brought to their attention, there's no invasion of privacy. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I mean, I don't think they should monitor phone conversations and texts. But if something is brought to their attention, it's a different story. Like a teacher shouldn't create a Facebook or Myspace account under a different name and befriend students. That's the same as not wanting to know your residents if they go out and drink and post pictures on Facebook. It's not my place to know that, so I don't want that connection.

My understanding is that they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This moved it down from a criminal offense to more of a traffic ticket. It's something you get cited for, instead of being arrested and brought in. If someone gets caught and cited, for job interviews and other things like that, the consequences which are usually the worst part of having a drug charge, don't necessarily go away when it's decriminalized. However, the argument is that it costs a lot to arrest people, bring them in, book them, house them, and go through the court process. This includes paying for public defenders, judges, and the state attorney's office. So, when looking at financially troubled municipalities, many aren't willing to make this kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. However, in a place like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, it makes sense. The municipality now has more money to spend on public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's important because you don't want marijuana to be everywhere, all over the streets. There are other reasons why it shouldn't necessarily be legalized. For example, if it were completely legalized, it could be sold in gas stations, and people would be smoking it everywhere. That could lead to a lot of people smoking and driving, which is still taboo in many places. I also feel that it would be awkward for people. In terms of their effects, alcohol has more debilitating effects on motor skills, but marijuana has a more adverse effect on one's lifestyle. Both have their adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people exercise moderation, while others don't. It makes it hard to generalize about the substance because people react differently. However, I definitely think they both have their own adverse effects.
